summary: This document is a series of email exchanges from May 2008 between FBI and U.S. Attorney's Office (USAFLS) personnel regarding the federal prosecution of Jeffrey Epstein. The emails discuss concerns about further delays in the case, statute of limitations issues, the impact on victims, and the terms of a potential plea deal. They reveal internal frustration with the handling of the case and the influence of Epstein's legal team.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central subject of the prosecution. The emails discuss the case against him for child exploitation, potential plea deals, and his defense arguments.

persons.name: Acosta
persons.context: Mentioned as being involved in presenting arguments to the Deputy Attorney General (DAG) to prevent further delays in the Epstein prosecution.

connections.description: Acosta, as U.S. Attorney, was involved in the federal prosecution against Epstein, specifically in arguing against delays in the case.

events.title: Internal Emails on Epstein Case Delays
events.description: FBI and U.S. Attorney's Office personnel exchange emails expressing concern that the Deputy Attorney General (DAG) might allow Epstein's counsel to present further arguments, potentially stalling the case. They discuss statute of limitations issues and the negative impact of delay.

events.title: Interview with Victim 'El'
events.description: The FBI interviewed a victim referred to as 'El'. She stated she told Epstein her true age (believed to be 14 or 15) and that Epstein told her he did not care about age. Phone records showed contact when she was 16.

events.title: Potential Plea Deal Negotiations
events.description: Emails reference an existing deal Epstein signed 'several months ago' requiring him to plead to uncharged crimes and pay damages. There is concern further delay will allow him to escape these terms. Another email mentions Epstein wanting 'to do less time' than the originally discussed 2-year deal.

events.title: Grand Jury Nearing Expiration
events.description: The prosecution notes the grand jury being used is set to expire soon, that it has heard over a dozen hours of testimony, and is invested and wants to indict.

keyFacts: Prosecutors expressed significant internal frustration that the Epstein case was being treated differently than other child exploitation cases, despite involving 'more than 20 known child victims'.
A key concern was the statute of limitations under state law (believed to be two years), which threatened to bar prosecution for a 'second set' of victims if the case was delayed further.
The prosecution was actively working to prevent further delays, with the U.S. Attorney (Acosta) preparing to present arguments to the Deputy Attorney General (DAG) on May 28, 2008.
Victim testimony indicated Epstein was aware of victims' minor status, with one victim ('El') stating she told him her age (14 or 15) and he said he 'did not care about age'.
The emails reference a pre-negotiated deal where Epstein had agreed to plead to uncharged crimes and pay damages to victims, a term he could escape if the case was stalled.
